I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The Terai, the flat river plain of southern Nepal with fertile alluvial soils, occupies about 
17% of the country’s total land area and accounts for 50% of its total population.1 The Terai is 
seen as the granary of Nepal. The Terai is Nepal’s most important agricultural region and 
dominates the production of major crops such as rice, wheat, pulses, sugarcane, jute, and 
maize. The Terai has a long history of floods affecting farmland, crops, and livestock, with 
impacts to lives, livelihood, property, and food security of poor communities. In August 2017, 
about 1.7 million people in the Terai were affected by flooding, with damage estimated by the 
government to be $584.7 million. The six subprojects have an estimated population of 1.8 
million, with more than 70,000 persons exposed to the 1-in-50-year flood. Of these, 84% have 
rural-based agricultural livelihoods, which are frequently affected by flooding. 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is supporting the Government of Nepal to address 
flood risk in the Terai region through the Priority River Basin Flood Risk Management Project. 
The project aims to reduce flood-related economic and social losses in six priority river basins in 
the Terai region of Nepal by strengthening integrated disaster risk management approaches.2 
The project will strengthen and build the capacity of the Department of Water Resources and 
irrigation (DWRI) and Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM), (the implementing 
agencies)  to  manage  flood  risks  and  provide  training  to  local  communities  on  flood  risk 
reduction.  It  will  contribute  to  improved  infrastructure,  increased  agricultural  and  livestock 
production, and disaster risk management by protecting agricultural land from flooding, adopting 
eco-friendly technologies, and promoting water disaster risk reduction activities. 
 
3.  The project is aligned with the following impact: social and economic losses because of 
water induced disasters reduced.3 The project will have the following outcome: resilience of 
communities to flood risks of selected river basins in the Terai region improved. The project will 
have three outputs: (i) flood protection infrastructure and maintenance system improved, (ii) 
flood forecasting and response systems enhanced, and (iii) flood prevention and preparedness 
capacity improved. The government has requested (i) a concessional loan of $40.00 million 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, and (ii) a grant not exceeding $10.00 million from ADB’s 
Special Funds resources (Asian Development Fund) to help finance the project. 
   
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  The  transaction  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  capacity  building  for  the 
implementing  agencies  to  implement  integrated  flood  risk  management  of  the  project  and 
improve sustainability of the infrastructure constructed under the project. This transaction TA is 
currently  listed  in  ADB’s  country  operations  business  plan  for  Nepal,  2020–2022  as 
Implementation  Support  for  the  Priority  River Basin  Flood  Risk  Management  Project.4 The 
transaction TA is proposed to be attached rather than part of the loan to allow for efficient 
consultant recruitment and management and close supervision by ADB.

5.  The TA will support the DWRI and the DHM with implementation, including the following: 
(i) review current asset management systems; (ii) propose improved asset monitoring and 
management systems; and (iii) provide capacity building to the DHM, DWRI, and provincial and 
local governments. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1:  Strategic flood risk management planning improved. The TA will (i) build 
capacity  of  the  DWRI,  provincial  governments,  and  local  governments  (municipalities)  in 
prioritizing flood protection works through consultant support and tailored training program and(ii) 
support the implementation of the Priority River Basin Flood Risk Management Project. 
 
7.  Output 2: Flood infrastructure asset management improved. The TA will (i) support 
the  DWRI  to  develop  a  simple  asset  management  system  for  embankments  (geographic 
information  system-based  open  freeware),  and  (ii)  will  provide  guidance  to  the  DWRI  on 
improving monitoring, evaluation, and maintenance of the flood management infrastructure. 
 
8.   Output 3: Flood preparedness improved. The TA will support the DHM to develop the 
flood forecasting and early warning systems through international consultant support. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,315,000 of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6) and (ii) $750,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Netherlands Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership Facility. 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
10.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space,  office supplies,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  government  was  informed  that 
approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants, and 
procure  goods.  ADB  will  evaluate  the  progress  of  the  TA  through  regular  consultations, 
including regular review missions including meetings with stakeholders. The Ministry of Energy, 
Water Resources and Irrigation will be the executing agency.
